articles.headline: Financial Decisions to Make as You Divorce
articles.snippet: Divorcing couples often don’t think of all the financial problems that can arrive after the split. Here’s a list of issues to discuss before the paperwork is final.
articles.abstract: Divorcing couples often don’t think of all the financial problems that can arrive after the split. Here’s a list of issues to discuss before the paperwork is final.
articles.lead_paragraph: Divorce may be one of the most damaging financial events in the lives of those who go through it, but that isn’t always immediately clear to a couple about to split up.

articles.headline: Bubbles at a Discount for Consumers Trading Down
articles.snippet: Conspicuous spending on luxury items like Champagne is not considered fashionable during a global recession.
articles.abstract: Conspicuous spending on luxury items like Champagne is not considered fashionable during a global recession.
articles.lead_paragraph: ÉPERNAY, France  For generations of French Champagne makers, the threat of calamity has been a constant companion, whether it is winter freezes or spring frosts, phylloxera parasites or Nazi occupiers.

articles.headline: More Than Ever, You Can Say That on Television
articles.snippet: Research has shown that vulgarities are being used more often, and in earlier hours, on prime-time television.
articles.abstract: Research has shown that vulgarities are being used more often, and in earlier hours, on prime-time television.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES  On many nights this fall, it has been possible to tune in to broadcast network television during prime time and hear a character call someone else a “douche.”

articles.headline: Worried About Losing Tax Revenue, Congress to Investigate Airlines’ Fees
articles.snippet: The additional fees that irk travelers, for the most part, are not taxed. The government says that fare increases in disguise are costing it extra revenue.
articles.abstract: The additional fees that irk travelers, for the most part, are not taxed. The government says that fare increases in disguise are costing it extra revenue.
articles.lead_paragraph: When airlines charge extra fees, are they really just another fare increase in disguise?

articles.headline: Obama Walks a Delicate Tightrope on His 1st Trip as President to China
articles.snippet: The contentious issue of China’s currency is on the agenda, but Chinese leaders are not without some counter-arguments against Washington.
articles.abstract: The contentious issue of China’s currency is on the agenda, but Chinese leaders are not without some counter-arguments against Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  Against the backdrop of a tentative global recovery, President Obama and China’s leaders will meet in Beijing next week to discuss how to improve relations between the world’s reigning economic superpower and its greatest challenger.

articles.headline: Russian Deal on Afghan Supply Route Not Done Yet
articles.snippet: The difficulty in establishing a supply corridor for the Afghan war over Russian airspace is the latest hurdle in establishing cooperation with the U.S.
articles.abstract: The difficulty in establishing a supply corridor for the Afghan war over Russian airspace is the latest hurdle in establishing cooperation with the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When he met President Dmitri A. Medvedev of Russia in April, President Obama sought to open an important new supply corridor for Afghanistan by flying American troops and weapons through Russian airspace. Visiting Moscow in July, he sealed a deal for as many as 4,500 flights a year, in what he called a “substantial contribution” to the war and a sign of improving relations with Russia.

articles.headline: High Costs Weigh on Troop Debate for Afghan War
articles.snippet: The budget implications of President Obama’s decision about sending more troops to Afghanistan are adding pressure to limit the commitment, officials say.
articles.abstract: The budget implications of President Obama’s decision about sending more troops to Afghanistan are adding pressure to limit the commitment, officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: While President Obama’s decision about sending more troops to Afghanistan is primarily a military one, it also has substantial budget implications that are adding pressure to limit the commitment, senior administration officials say.

articles.headline: China’s Role as Lender Alters Obama’s Visit
articles.snippet: As President Obama begins his visit to China, he will likely spend more time reassuring Beijing than pushing reform.
articles.abstract: As President Obama begins his visit to China, he will likely spend more time reassuring Beijing than pushing reform.
articles.lead_paragraph: When President Obama visits China for the first time on Sunday, he will, in many ways, be assuming the role of profligate spender coming to pay his respects to his banker.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Michael Wines and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Home Builders (You Heard That Right) Get a Gift
articles.snippet: Analysts say home builders will be among the biggest beneficiaries of a new tax break.
articles.abstract: Analysts say home builders will be among the biggest beneficiaries of a new tax break.
articles.lead_paragraph: ON Nov. 6, President Obama signed the Worker, Homeownership and Business Assistance Act of 2009 into law, extending unemployment benefits by 20 weeks and renewing the first-time homebuyer tax credit until next April.

articles.headline: Is There a Method in Cellphone Madness?
articles.snippet: Despite all those wild pricing plans, American cellphone users spend about 5 cents a minute on talk time and a penny a text message — lower than anywhere else in the developed world.
articles.abstract: Despite all those wild pricing plans, American cellphone users spend about 5 cents a minute on talk time and a penny a text message — lower than anywhere else in the developed world.
articles.lead_paragraph: HERE’S a consolation prize to the millions who recoil in bafflement from cellphone companies’ labyrinthine price plans, with their ever more intricate arrays of minutes, messages and megabytes: Economists don’t understand them, either.

articles.headline: At Bloomberg, Modest Strategy to Rule the World
articles.snippet: Bloomberg L.P., using the cash stream from its namesake terminals, is on a campaign to become the most influential news organization — anywhere.
articles.abstract: Bloomberg L.P., using the cash stream from its namesake terminals, is on a campaign to become the most influential news organization — anywhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: PLOPPED in a white leather chair in a small office in Bloomberg L.P.’s Manhattan headquarters, Andrew Lack knows exactly how to articulate the aspirations of this 28-year-old media and technology company.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: In House, Many Spoke With One Voice: Lobbyists’
articles.snippet: More than a dozen lawmakers’ statements on the health care debate were ghostwritten by lobbyists working for Genentech, a biotechnology company.
articles.abstract: More than a dozen lawmakers’ statements on the health care debate were ghostwritten by lobbyists working for Genentech, a biotechnology company.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  In the official record of the historic House debate on overhauling health care, the speeches of many lawmakers echo with similarities. Often, that was no accident.

articles.headline: Investigators Study Tangle of Clues on Fort Hood Suspect
articles.snippet: Investigators are trying to determine whether Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan was a terrorist driven by extremism, a troubled loner, or both.
articles.abstract: Investigators are trying to determine whether Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan was a terrorist driven by extremism, a troubled loner, or both.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  When Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan took his two handguns and headed for Fort Hood on Nov. 5, he left behind in his spartan apartment his new business cards. Now they are one more clue for investigators of the 13 killings he is charged with, hinting at the road not taken.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and James Dao

articles.headline: Portrait of 9/11 ‘Jackal’ Emerges as He Awaits Trial
articles.snippet: The boastful and fiercely independent Khalid Shaikh Mohammed has never fit the mold of Al Qaeda chieftain.
articles.abstract: The boastful and fiercely independent Khalid Shaikh Mohammed has never fit the mold of Al Qaeda chieftain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Not long after he was rousted from bed and seized in a predawn raid in Pakistan in March 2003, Khalid Shaikh Mohammed gave his captors two demands: He wanted a lawyer, and he wanted to be taken to New York.

articles.headline: Experts Outline Hurdles for Defense of Hasan
articles.snippet: Defending Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, accused of the Fort Hood killings, is the kind of test many lawyers dread, and some live for.
articles.abstract: Defending Maj. Nidal Malik Hasan, accused of the Fort Hood killings, is the kind of test many lawyers dread, and some live for.
articles.lead_paragraph: Defending the man accused of premeditated murder in the Nov. 5 shooting rampage at Fort Hood is the kind of test that many lawyers dread, and that some live for.

articles.headline: MSNBC Presses Obama on Campaign Promises
articles.snippet: MSNBC hosts are calling on the president to keep his campaign promises about health care and other issues.
articles.abstract: MSNBC hosts are calling on the president to keep his campaign promises about health care and other issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: If President Obama happened to glance at “The Rachel Maddow Show” last Monday, he might have winced.

articles.headline: Writing a Sports Column Far From Print, and the Game
articles.snippet: How a sports columnist’s early commitment to the Web is subtly changing a corner of sports journalism.
articles.abstract: How a sports columnist’s early commitment to the Web is subtly changing a corner of sports journalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 1998, a Boston Globe profile of an obscure online sports commentator began simply: “Get used to this name: Bill Simmons.”

articles.headline: Taking Aim at Student Muckrakers
articles.snippet: A subpoena seeks to test whether Medill students who investigated the murder conviction of Anthony McKinney were actually journalists.
articles.abstract: A subpoena seeks to test whether Medill students who investigated the murder conviction of Anthony McKinney were actually journalists.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since 1992, Prof. David Protess at the Medill school at Northwestern University has worked with undergraduate journalism students to investigate cases in which prosecutors appear to have taken aim at the wrong people. That might be about to happen again, only this time the students themselves would be the targets.

articles.headline: Stimulus and Exports Help Ease Japan’s Recession
articles.snippet: The economy grew at an annual rate of 4.8 percent in the third quarter and appeared to bring the country out of its worst recession in the postwar era.
articles.abstract: The economy grew at an annual rate of 4.8 percent in the third quarter and appeared to bring the country out of its worst recession in the postwar era.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO  Japan’s economy grew at a robust annual rate of 4.8 percent in the third quarter as stimulus spending and a rebound in exports appeared to bring the country firmly out of its worst recession in the postwar era.

articles.headline: U.S. Asks More From Pakistan in War
articles.snippet: The Obama administration warned Pakistan that failing to expand its fight against the Taliban and Al Qaeda would undercut the new strategy and troop increase for Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration warned Pakistan that failing to expand its fight against the Taliban and Al Qaeda would undercut the new strategy and troop increase for Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration is stepping up pressure on Pakistan to expand and reorient its fight against the Taliban and Al Qaeda, warning that failing to do so would undercut the new strategy and troop increase for Afghanistan that President Obama is preparing to approve, American officials say.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Governor Crist Becomes a Right-Wing Target
articles.snippet: As governor, Charlie Crist backed President Obama’s stimulus plan. That move is endangering his Senate run.
articles.abstract: As governor, Charlie Crist backed President Obama’s stimulus plan. That move is endangering his Senate run.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEWBERRY, Fla.  In retrospect, even Charlie Crist admits that “the optics” of The Hug are not great.

articles.headline: Money Trickles North as Mexicans Help Relatives
articles.snippet: Some Mexican families are scraping together what they can to support unemployed relatives in the United States.
articles.abstract: Some Mexican families are scraping together what they can to support unemployed relatives in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAHUATLÁN, Mexico  During the best of the times, Miguel Salcedo’s son, an illegal immigrant in San Diego, would be sending home hundreds of dollars a month to support his struggling family in Mexico. But at times like these, with the American economy out of whack and his son out of work, Mr. Salcedo finds himself doing what he never imagined he would have to do: wiring pesos north.

articles.headline: Drug Makers Raise Prices in Face of Health Care Reform
articles.snippet: Critics say the industry is trying to establish a higher price base before Congress passes legislation that tries to curb drug spending in coming years.
articles.abstract: Critics say the industry is trying to establish a higher price base before Congress passes legislation that tries to curb drug spending in coming years.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as drug makers promise to support Washington’s health care overhaul by shaving $8 billion a year off the nation’s drug costs after the legislation takes effect, the industry has been raising its prices at the fastest rate in years.

articles.headline: G.M. Is Said to Soon Begin Paying U.S. Debt
articles.snippet: The company, which received $50 billion in taxpayer aid, is expected to make its first payment in late December.
articles.abstract: The company, which received $50 billion in taxpayer aid, is expected to make its first payment in late December.
articles.lead_paragraph: General Motors, which emerged from a government-ordered bankruptcy restructuring earlier this year, will begin paying back its debt to the United States and Canadian governments earlier than expected, a person with direct knowledge of G.M.’s plans said Sunday night.

articles.headline: G.M. Shows Signs of Recovery Despite New Loss
articles.snippet: G.M. said that while it was still losing money, it had stabilized enough to begin repaying a portion of its government loans.
articles.abstract: G.M. said that while it was still losing money, it had stabilized enough to begin repaying a portion of its government loans.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  General Motors, whose very survival was in doubt this year, is showing signs of life after its brief tour through bankruptcy this summer.
